tweet:
@Yozzo @UK_SPF @Ofcom @BAIComms @bt_uk @LouLancaster @DCMS Yeah sure, if it was a full-day event then there's usually speakers from other stakeholders like satellite, broadcast, military, utilities, space-observation, WiFi & 100 others

But this is a 90-min webinar about network densification, future demand patterns & new mid/high bands
name: Dean Bubley

tweet: @disruptivedean @UK_SPF @Ofcom @BAIComms @bt_uk @LouLancaster @DCMS Offload would be the keyword. Also broadcasting is indeed interesting regarding on data-heavy private networks (event, stadiums, regional/local broadcasting)
name: YOZZO

tweet:
@Yozzo @UK_SPF @Ofcom @BAIComms @bt_uk @LouLancaster @DCMS I'd also say that in the UK, broadcast TV content (eg BBC, realtime sports etc) isn't as much of a big deal over cellular networks compared to streaming stuff like YouTube

Most UK TV is watched on terrestrial broadcast, or over fixed home broadband
name: Dean Bubley

tweet:
@Yozzo @UK_SPF @Ofcom @BAIComms @bt_uk @LouLancaster @DCMS Typically they have spectrum <1GHz. That's relevant for coverage, but really not a big deal in terms of overall data volumes. Not relevant for URLLC or data-heavy private networks

More relevant are the military, satellite co's & fixed-link users like utilities
name: Dean Bubley

tweet:
@Yozzo @UK_SPF @Ofcom @BAIComms @bt_uk @LouLancaster @DCMS Yeah sure, if it was a full-day event then there's usually speakers from other stakeholders like satellite, broadcast, military, utilities, space-observation, WiFi & 100 others

But this is a 90-min webinar about network densification, future demand patterns & new mid/high bands
name: Dean Bubley

tweet: @disruptivedean @UK_SPF @Ofcom @BAIComms @bt_uk @LouLancaster @DCMS Offload would be the keyword. Also broadcasting is indeed interesting regarding on data-heavy private networks (event, stadiums, regional/local broadcasting)
name: YOZZO

tweet:
@Yozzo @UK_SPF @Ofcom @BAIComms @bt_uk @LouLancaster @DCMS I'd also say that in the UK, broadcast TV content (eg BBC, realtime sports etc) isn't as much of a big deal over cellular networks compared to streaming stuff like YouTube

Most UK TV is watched on terrestrial broadcast, or over fixed home broadband
name: Dean Bubley

tweet:
@Yozzo @UK_SPF @Ofcom @BAIComms @bt_uk @LouLancaster @DCMS Typically they have spectrum <1GHz. That's relevant for coverage, but really not a big deal in terms of overall data volumes. Not relevant for URLLC or data-heavy private networks

More relevant are the military, satellite co's & fixed-link users like utilities
name: Dean Bubley
